On this segment we look under the hood—options probabilities, volatility, trading strategies, futures, you name it—so your trading mechanics are built to manage more winners.

item.title: SPY / VIX Positive Correlation
item.description:
It is well know that the S&P and VIX have a strong negative correlation. This relationship is why VIX is referred to as the “fear index”. 

However, the past few weeks, both the S&P and VIX have been moving together. What does this mean for the weeks to come? Will this relationship continue? Or does it provide us insight into the direction of either SPY or VIX?

Join Tom and Tony to find out!

item.title: Why Not Cheaper Strangles?
item.description:
What are the tradeoffs between trading high delta strangles vs low delta strangles? And why?

Although 2 SD (5 delta) strangles seem safer because of their lower risk, profits and return on capital are greatly sacrificed while POP is much higher. Higher delta strangles (1 SD and 1⁄2 SD) are more risky, but make up for it with their larger ROC and higher raw P/L.

item.title: Equity Index Divergences
item.description:
Although the equity indexes are still correlated, we find IWM has been bucking the trend more often in the last two years than it did on average since 2010. 

However, this phenomenon may work to our advantage...since a lower correlation means more diversification, replacing some SPY or QQQ with IWM in your portfolio may reduce overall portfolio volatility.

item.title: What's More Volatile?
item.description:
Trading options has always been considered a “riskier” investment by the financial media. Most financial advisors will recommend a buy and hold strategy because it’s considered profitable and less risky than options. 

But is this actually true? Does simply buying stock and holding it over 15 years outperform an options portfolio? And is it really less risky? Tune in to find out!

item.title: Diversifying by Strategy
item.description:
Short premium positions can be diversified with respect to strategy choice.

This an effective way to capitalize on the directional dynamics of an asset while protecting a proportion of portfolio capital from outlier losses.

Join Tom and Tony as they take a look at how combining two types of directionally neutral strategies (strangles and iron condors) can affect portfolio performance.

item.title: Replicating Stock with Options
item.description:
Options can be used as a more capital efficient way to replicate stock in a portfolio. There are a variety of ways to reflect a bullish bias, such as buying a call. But a long call is a low probability, negative theta trade. 

Over the years, we have discussed a variety of bullish strategies, from short puts to ZEBRAs. Of the tastytrade strategies, which is most optimal for replicating stock?

item.title: How Delta Changes Risk
item.description:
Regardless of the delta, managing early has reduced around 50% of the overall risk and around 70% of the outlier risk on a trade by trade basis compared to holding to expiration.

The difference between a higher and lower delta strangle is the reduced swings and reduced premium for lower delta strangles. However, keep in mind that the size of an outlier can still be significant for any short strangle regardless of delta.

item.title: Crypto All-Time Highs
item.description:
In the past week, we have seen new all-time highs for Bitcoin, Ethereum, Polkadot, and Solana. These coins are just slightly off of their ATH, consolidating before their next move.

Historically, the crypto market sees a positive average return following an all time high. However, that may not always be the case and history doesn’t necessarily always repeat itself.

item.title: Product Indifference
item.description:
The results from selling strangles across unrelated and generally uncorrelated underlyings were very similar when the delta, premium, and price of the underlying were considered. 

We can form the following conjecture based on these results: the only tangible differences between underlyings that affect risk and return are the prices and IVs of the underlyings in question.

item.title: Relationship between POP Delta and Volatility
item.description:
When selling premium, one minus delta has been shown as being a good proxy for the probability of profit (POP).

If you sold a 30 delta put, you would expect to have roughly a 70% POP. We use this simple calculation every day when placing trades, but does this relationship for delta and POP hold even as volatility changes?

item.title: How Theta and IV are Correlated
item.description: 30 delta strangles have roughly 2x the theta of a 10 delta strangle and roughly 1.5x the theta of a 20 delta strangle. item.title: Historical Crypto Rallies
item.description:
Crypto is becoming a huge asset class. Retail traders need to understand what their portfolio crypto exposure can lead to in the short and long term.

The global crypto market cap has grown to $2.76 Trillion, up 30% from the Market Measures segment about historical crypto drawdowns.

For the past year, crypto has seen a 10% or greater rally each month. Following these moves, there are normally corrections before the next surge.

item.title: How Bad Was 2020: Stocks vs Options
item.description:
In the worst short-lived selloff in history, selling naked puts could have seen worse losses than the drawdown in a long stock portfolio, but only if your exposure was large enough.

Because by adding any risk definition (long wings), rolling down calls, diversifying products, and diversifying IVs you would have reduced the drawdown seen in this portfolio, we look at worst-case-scenario on both to make a real comparison.

item.title: Earnings Performance Across Sectors
item.description:
As we round out the halfway point of this 3rd quarter earnings season, we thought it would be interesting to see how 1-day post earnings performance has varied across sectors. Even though earnings have been poor relative to the last quarter, the market is still rallying. It seems that the fundamentals may not be the key driver for market moves.

How have the sectors performed following their earnings? Which sector has had the best performance? Watch to find out!

item.title: How Naked Should My Trade Be?
item.description:
On average, buying wings is a tradeoff between portfolio consistency in the short term, at the expense of long term profitability.

Solely maximizing profitability without considering risk management is the quickest way to get in trouble. For those considering taking some risk off the table, start with 5∆ wings as they have a modest but noticeable reduction in risk/return compared to selling naked.

item.title: Distribution of Implied Volatility
item.description: tastytrade looks at how the distribution of implied volatility has changed since the start of COVID.Over the past 2 years, we have seen extremely high levels of volatility in the markets, seeing the highest ever close in March of 2020. While current VIX levels may seem low relative to what we have seen recently, they are actually near the median of what we saw before COVID. How much has COVID skewed the distribution of implied volatility?

item.title: What Does Buying Wings Do?
item.description:
On average, the cost of insuring a strangle against outlier losses (buying wings) is between 20% and 50% of the price of the long option.

In higher IVR situations, around half of the premium of the long option is used as the “vig” to pay for the outlier protection. In lower IVR, where the size of price moves is lower, the same “vig” will cost around 20% of the long option premium.

The spread may narrow over time since SPY’s spread is less than 15% of Bitcoin’s current IV-HV spread.

item.title: How Wide to Make Your Wings
item.description:
While trading strangles is the ideal strategy to stay neutral from a probability of profit (POP) standpoint, in smaller accounts, the buying power requirement (BPR) is sometimes too high.

The solution to this is to trade iron condors. However, the POP of iron condors is less than a strangle, so how can traders adjust the width of their wings to ensure they are still receiving good returns for the risk they are taking? tastytrade digs in.
